[[User:Oct13|Oct13]] ([[User talk:Oct13|talk]]) 16:59, 3 April 2012 (UTC) == Satan as the serpent of Eden == “Satan is often identified as the serpent who convinced Eve to eat the forbidden fruit; thus, Satan has often been depicted as a serpent. Though this identification is not present in the Adam and Eve narrative, this interpretation goes back at least as far as the time of the writing of the book of Revelation, which specifically identifies Satan as being the serpent (Rev. 20:2).” Strictly speaking, is this true? As far as I can tell, Revelation doesn’t specifically identify Satan as being the same serpent who spoke to Eve in the Garden of Eden, certainly not in any translation that I’ve ever come across. Revelation could well be alluding to the serpent from Genesis but it doesn’t specifically identify Satan as being that same serpent. Some examples of the verse in question: “And he laid hold on the dragon, that old serpent, who is the Devil, and Satan, and bound him a thousand years.” “He seized the dragon, that ancient serpent, who is the devil, or Satan, and bound him for a thousand years.” “He seized the dragon, the old serpent, which is the devil and Satan, and bound him for a thousand years,” I think that something like this would be more appropriate: Satan is often identified as the serpent who convinced Eve to eat the forbidden fruit; thus, Satan has often been depicted as a serpent. Though this identification is not present in the Adam and Eve narrative, this interpretation goes back at least as far as the time of Justin Martyr, who, in his Dialogue with Trypho, specifically identified Satan as being the serpent of Eden. — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/78.148.156.230|78.148.156.230]] ([[User talk:78.148.156.230|talk]]) 22:08, 3 January 2012 (UTC) == Devils, plural == This article leaves no scope for plural "devils".
